text: Either I'm confused or they are. Multiple dispatch doesn't give speed, it gives convenient and generic code. And Julia's selling point has never been that it's a fast language. C was fast 40 years ago. It's that it's fast and dynamic. Zig is static, right?

elements.text: Either I'm confused or they are. Multiple dispatch doesn't give speed, it gives convenient and generic code. And Julia's selling point has never been that it's a fast language. C was fast 40 years ago. It's that it's fast and dynamic. Zig is static, right?

text: Yeah, I don't think comptime and multiple dispatch are comparable, I think the poster was just excited about the result earlier in the thread, where zig does some cool type stuff at `comptime` which I guess reminded him of some of the optimizations julia is capable of using its type system.

elements.text: Yeah, I don't think comptime and multiple dispatch are comparable, I think the poster was just excited about the result earlier in the thread, where zig does some cool type stuff at
which I guess reminded him of some of the optimizations julia is capable of using its type system.

text:
>  And Julia’s selling point has never been that it’s a fast language.
I would disagree, I think that’s one of the primary selling points of Julia

elements.text: And Julia’s selling point has never been that it’s a fast language.
I would disagree, I think that’s one of the primary selling points of Julia

text:
Also, we don’t have return types, but you can do this with argument types in Julia:

```string_if_less_than_ten(x) = x < 10 ? String : Float64
foo(x::Int64, y::string_if_less_than_ten(8)) = (x, y)
foo(4, "foo")```
It’s hard to imagine why you’d want to, but it is legal.  :wink:

elements.text: Also, we don’t have return types, but you can do this with argument types in Julia:

string_if_less_than_ten(x) = x < 10 ? String : Float64
foo(x::Int64, y::string_if_less_than_ten(8)) = (x, y)
foo(4, "foo")
It’s hard to imagine why you’d want to, but it is legal.

text: What I meant was: Julia's selling point isnt JUST that it's fast. Faster languages than Julia has existed before I was born. So saying "Rust/Zig/Crystal/C++ is fast, no reason to learn Julia" misses the point
